content.question: How can NDBs be used for navigation near the destination aerodrome?

options.A: As a marker beacon along the final approach segment.
options.B: As a VOR beacon to track a localiser signal along the final approach segment.
options.C: As a locator beacon to start the final approach segment.
options.D: As a DME beacon to give range information along the final approach segment.

key_points: Learning Objective 062
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 062.02.02.01.07: Define a ‘locator beacon’: an LF/MF NDB used as an aid to final approach usually with a range of 10-25 NM. NDBs are non-directional beacons that transmit a simple carrier wave with a modulation to overlay the morse code identifier. They are a ground station consisting of just one aerial for transmission. The ADF (Automatic Direction Finder) is the equipment in the cockpit which measures the direction from which the NDB carrier wave signal came, and points a needle directly towards the NDB in question on one of the pilot's instruments. NDBs are split into two use categories, en-route (for long range navigation) and locator beacons (for terminal procedures). As specified in the LO above, locator beacons are low powered NDBs, and have short ranges of 10 - 25 nm. They are often used as beacons denoting the approach holding pattern, or the final approach fix. They may be co-located with a marker beacon (the outer marker usually), but NDBs are different from marker beacons, which people do occasionally get mixed up.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
At which position would an aircraft at an altitude of 5000 ft AMSL receive the strongest signal from VNC NDB (27°04.3’N, 082°26.4’W)?

key_points: The learning objectives state: State that the range of an NDB over sea is better than over land due to better ground wave propagation over seawater than over land
Furthermore, in general, the closer aircraft will receive the stronger signal
At position C, the aircraft would receive the signal unaffected by ground clutter and terrain, resulting in the strongest signal
learning.explanation: The learning objectives state: State that the range of an NDB over sea is better than over land due to better ground wave propagation over seawater than over land. Furthermore, in general, the closer aircraft will receive the stronger signal. At position C, the aircraft would receive the signal unaffected by ground clutter and terrain, resulting in the strongest signal. Coastal Refraction Coastal refraction is caused by radio waves travelling faster over sea than over land. This results in a change in the propagation direction when a wave crosses a boundary between sea and land. The refraction at the boundary of land and water is a function of the propagation speeds over land and water plus the incidence angle relative to the boundary. Radio waves speed up over water, causing the wave front to bend away from its normal path and pull it towards the coast. This phenomenon is negligible when the aircraft is perpendicular (90°) to the coast as the wave continues to propagate straight through the boundary. The magnitude of the refraction increases as the incidence increases. The effect of coastal refraction can be minimized by flying higher.

options.B: 5 degrees.

content.question: To determine the VOR radial, the aircraft VOR receiver…

options.A: uses pulse techniques.
options.B: measures the time difference between sending the interrogation signal and receiving the transponder signal.
options.C: measures the phase difference between the reference phase and the variable phase signals.
options.D: measures the time difference between reception of the two signals transmitted by the ground installation.

key_points: A VHF Omni-directional Range (VOR) is used as a navigation beacon for aircraft
Aircraft with a receiving unit will be able to determine their position relative to the VOR beacon
The frequency of VOR’s appear in the Very High Frequency (VHF) range, from 108
learning.explanation: A VHF Omni-directional Range (VOR) is used as a navigation beacon for aircraft. Aircraft with a receiving unit will be able to determine their position relative to the VOR beacon. The frequency of VOR’s appear in the Very High Frequency (VHF) range, from 108.00 to 117.95 MHz. A VOR ground station sends a highly directional signal, by making use of a so called phased array antenna. Together with this signal, the VOR sends a 30 Hz reference signal which is equal in all direction. The phase difference between the reference signal and the highly directional signal, is the bearing from the VOR station relative to Magnetic North. A VOR receiver works by comparing the phase relationship between a reference signal and a variable signal.

key_points: This Navigation Display is showing an Expanded ILS/APP mode/ The "lubber line" at the top in the centre says that the heading is 280° (M), and there are three other lines emanating from the aircraft symbol

The solid line to the right of centre (pointing at 297°) comes directly out of the CDI (Course Deviation Indicator) at the bottom, meaning that it is the selected course (in this case it is the course of the ILS)

learning.explanation: This Navigation Display is showing an Expanded ILS/APP mode/ The "lubber line" at the top in the centre says that the heading is 280° (M), and there are three other lines emanating from the aircraft symbol. The solid line to the right of centre (pointing at 297°) comes directly out of the CDI (Course Deviation Indicator) at the bottom, meaning that it is the selected course (in this case it is the course of the ILS). The dotted line pointing at 260° has that number box at the top, meaning that it must be the selected heading bug. This leaves only one option for the solid line with crosses on it pointing at 272°, it must be the track indication. This makes sense as the wind arrow would cause a drift in this direction, and 8° left drift is therefore realistic in the scenario. Also, there is nothing else that this line could really be, after looking at the other possibilities. As drift is always from heading (where we point) to track (where we fly), then the drift here is classed as left drift, and we can see very easily that the difference is 8°.

Ignoring any effects of turn radius, and assuming an appropriate intercept, choose the correct statement from the below.

options.A: To intercept QDR 270°, continue on the present heading and turn left away from the NDB.
options.B: To intercept QDM 315°, continue on the present heading and turn right towards the NDB.

QDM - Magnetic bearing to the station
QDR - Magnetic bearing from the station
learning.explanation: The figure shows the current location of the aircraft in relation to the NDB. QDM - Magnetic bearing to the station. QDR - Magnetic bearing from the station. content.question: The shoreline/coastal effect is caused by refraction of the radio waves. What is one factor influencing the error of the bearing?

options.A: distance of the NDB from the coast
options.B: weather conditions
options.C: conditions over the sea

key_points: Radio waves speed up over water due to the reduced absorption of energy (attenuation) compared to what which occurs over land
If the radio waves cross the coastline at an angle, this speeding up causes the wave front to bend (refract) away from it’s normal path and pull it "towards the coast" as seen above
For an aircraft flying over the sea, the error puts the aircraft position closer to the coast than its actual position
learning.explanation: Radio waves speed up over water due to the reduced absorption of energy (attenuation) compared to what which occurs over land. If the radio waves cross the coastline at an angle, this speeding up causes the wave front to bend (refract) away from it’s normal path and pull it "towards the coast" as seen above. For an aircraft flying over the sea, the error puts the aircraft position closer to the coast than its actual position. The effect can be minimised by: Flying higher - a higher altitude minimises this coastal refraction effect. Using NDBs close to the coast - this reduces the effect of the error to the pilot, even though the waves bend just as much. Using signals that cross the coast at or near to 90° - where refraction would not take place.

content.question: The DME Line Of Position is a circle with radius:

options.A: the slant range and centre the DME-station.
options.B: the ground distance and centre the aircraft.
options.C: a the ground distance and centre the DME-station.
options.D: the slant range and centre the aircraft.

key_points: A DME is used for determining the distance from a ground DME transmitter
Compared to other VHF/UHF NAVAIDs, a DME is very accurate
The distance information can be used to determine the aircraft position or flying a track that is a constant distance from the station (this is referred to as a DME arc)
learning.explanation: A DME is used for determining the distance from a ground DME transmitter. Compared to other VHF/UHF NAVAIDs, a DME is very accurate. The distance information can be used to determine the aircraft position or flying a track that is a constant distance from the station (this is referred to as a DME arc). There are several way to plot a route on a chart: straight route plotted between radio beacons direct route plotted without reference to any paricular radio beacons and fixes are calculated along the track based on position lines plotted from radio beacons In general a position line is a circle with radius the ground distance between the point and the ground station and centre at the ground station. Pay attention: there are some quite similar questions regarding DME poistion lines with very different answer. The main problem is about the DME distance: should a pilot consider DME distace plotted on a chart like a Slant or a Ground Range distance ? In general we can affirm that there is a difference between Ground Range and Slant Range but that difference is negligible and not worth considering until you are VERY close to the beacon, at which point plotting becomes quite immaterial and difficult owing to the relatively rapid changes in distance, i.e. 3 NM change in range is not significant when 150 NM from the beacon but it is significant when you are only 5 NM from the beacon. As a rule of thumb, discrepancies only start to appear within 1 NM per 1,000' of height, e.g. when flying at 10,000' the discrepancies only start to appear within 10 NM, at 20,000 within 20 NM, etc. Even then, they are very small and hardly worth worrying about, e.g. at 35,000' 35 NM Ground Distance = 35.6 NM DME Distance, and 10 NM Gnd Dist = 12 NM DME Dist

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which of the figures depicts an Electronic Flight Instrument System (EFIS) display in Expanded (EXP) VOR/ILS mode with an VOR frequency selected?

options.A: Figure 1
options.B: Figure 4
options.C: Figure 5

key_points: A navigation Display (ND) provides a mode selectable flight progress display

The different display modes of the ND are the following: EXPANDED, MAP, or ARC mode: an expanded view of the compass rose, with the current heading at the top (“heading-up orientation”) VOR, FULL VOR, or ROSE VOR mode: the entire compass rose in a heading-up orientation APP or ROSE ILS mode: the entire compass rose in heading-up orientation, with only the ILS localiser visible, an additional glide slope indication appears to the right PLAN mode: the upcoming flight plan waypoints are depicted in a “north-up” orientation, the display range can be adjusted

The MAP (or ARC) mode of the ND usually displays information such as the selected and current track (or heading), the TAS and GS, the wind direction and speed, next waypoint distance, and weather radar information
learning.explanation: A navigation Display (ND) provides a mode selectable flight progress display. The different display modes of the ND are the following: EXPANDED, MAP, or ARC mode: an expanded view of the compass rose, with the current heading at the top (“heading-up orientation”) VOR, FULL VOR, or ROSE VOR mode: the entire compass rose in a heading-up orientation APP or ROSE ILS mode: the entire compass rose in heading-up orientation, with only the ILS localiser visible, an additional glide slope indication appears to the right PLAN mode: the upcoming flight plan waypoints are depicted in a “north-up” orientation, the display range can be adjusted. The MAP (or ARC) mode of the ND usually displays information such as the selected and current track (or heading), the TAS and GS, the wind direction and speed, next waypoint distance, and weather radar information. Some questions will ask you to determine the mode selected on a given ND. To do so you need to ask yourself two questions: Is it a Full-Rose (360° compass rose displayed) or an Expanded Mode (90° of the compass rose displayed with ±45° either side of the centerline)? As you can see, this information is not very relevant for this specific question as all the provided figures of ND are expanded modes. Is it a VOR/ILS mode or a NAV mode? The VOR/ILS mode will simply have the VOR or ILS transmitter frequency, course, and deviation scales displayed on the top right-hand corner of the ND, whereas the NAV mode will only display the TO waypoint, the distance, and the time to that waypoint. You’re looking for a VOR/ILS mode, where the frequency of the VOR is indicated at the bottom. Figure 1 and 6 indicate is a full VOR and a full ILS mode respectively, on figure 2 you can see the plan mode with a large part of the route displayed and the True North indication at the bottom, figure 3 has no navaid tuned (no identifier displayed = MAP), and finally Figure 5 indicates ‘ILS’ at the bottom. Figure 4, however, has the VOR indication at the bottom left-hand corner and its frequency on the right. A course deviation scale is also displayed and further confirms that ND is a VOR mode display.

content.question: Under what circumstances would an ADF bearing be affected by dip error?

options.A: The NDB being on a bearing at 45° to the aircraft’s longitudinal axis.
options.B: The aircraft flying at a low level in a mountainous area.
options.C: The aircraft banking or accelerating.

key_points: LOs reference 062
learning.explanation: LOs reference 062.02.02.05.03: Explain that the bank angle of the aircraft causes a dip error. Dip error is an inaccurate reading of the bearing information when the aircraft is in a bank. This is because the ADF receiver system was designed to work when in horizontal flight. When a turn is initiated, the indicated bearing is modified. The needle will cause an error towards the direction of whichever wing is banked down.

content.question: An aircraft is equipped with a DME receiver that can provide a read-out of ground speed. It is climbing on a heading of 270°(T), and is crossing the 330 radial from a VOR/DME station. The ground speed calculated by the DME computer is...

options.A: inaccurate because the aircraft is moving away from the station and the slant range error becomes more significant with distance.
options.B: exactly correct because the aircraft slant range is increasing at the ground speed due to the climb.
options.C: greater than the actual ground speed because the change in slant range is greater than the change in ground distance.
options.D: less than the actual ground speed because the change in slant range is smaller than the change in ground distance.

key_points: Some DME receivers have a setting that will read-out the aircraft's groundspeed when heading towards or away from the station, as well as an estimate of the time to the station
This is calculated by the DME receiver using the rate of change of the detected distance from the station
This means that flying anywhere other than directly to/from the station causes an unusable read out, as is the case in this question, where we are crossing the radials
learning.explanation: Some DME receivers have a setting that will read-out the aircraft's groundspeed when heading towards or away from the station, as well as an estimate of the time to the station. This is calculated by the DME receiver using the rate of change of the detected distance from the station. This means that flying anywhere other than directly to/from the station causes an unusable read out, as is the case in this question, where we are crossing the radials. Another thing to consider is that DME systems calculate slant range from the aircraft to the station, so the DME groundspeed calculations are more accurate when this slant range closely resembles ground distance, so when at low altitude and far away from the DME (within line of sight of course). In this question, our aircraft is crossing the 330 radial, and the slant distance is increasing a small amount, but by much less than our groundspeed, therefore, the groundspeed read-out on our DME will be lower than our actual groundspeed.

content.question: What is the minimum altitude that can be flown to receive a VHF direction-finding signal when 50 NM from the ground station?

key_points: VHF direction finding (VHF D/F) signals are simply standard VHF communication signals that you use to speak with ATC
ATC will then tell you a certain value that you can use for plotting the aircraft position or navigating with, depending on what you ask for, most commonly QDM, QDR or QTE

The range of a VHF D/F signal is therefore the same as any line-of-sight signal, which can only travel as far as a straight line on a curved globe, plus a very small addition for curvature due to atmospheric refraction
learning.explanation: VHF direction finding (VHF D/F) signals are simply standard VHF communication signals that you use to speak with ATC. ATC will then tell you a certain value that you can use for plotting the aircraft position or navigating with, depending on what you ask for, most commonly QDM, QDR or QTE. The range of a VHF D/F signal is therefore the same as any line-of-sight signal, which can only travel as far as a straight line on a curved globe, plus a very small addition for curvature due to atmospheric refraction. Thus, the curvature of Earth causes much of the surface to be in shadow. Therefore, higher flying aircraft are more likely to be detected because they are above that shadow. Knowing the heights of the radar station (H1) and a target (H2), the range is calculated with the line-of-sight formula: R = 1.23 (√ H1 + √ H2) Where: H1 = Altitude/ Height of the receiver in ft H2 = Elevation of the ground facility in ft R = Range in NM In our case (we assume the station is at sea level) we have: 50 = 1.23(√ H2) (50/1.23)2 = H2 H2 = 1655 ft minimum.

content.question:
On which of the following items does the range of VDF depend?
1. Line of sight formula
2. Power of transmitters
3. Intervening high ground

options.A: Only 2
options.B: Only 1 and 2

key_points: The VHF Direction Finder (VDF) is a means of providing a pilot with the direction to fly towards a ground station by means of a bearing
The bearing can be used to navigate to or from the station or to help establish a fixed position

The range of the VDF depends on the following: The formulae used to calculate the range of these radio waves is called the line of sight formulae and is as follows: Maximum theoretical range (in nm) = 1
learning.explanation: The VHF Direction Finder (VDF) is a means of providing a pilot with the direction to fly towards a ground station by means of a bearing. The bearing can be used to navigate to or from the station or to help establish a fixed position. The range of the VDF depends on the following: The formulae used to calculate the range of these radio waves is called the line of sight formulae and is as follows: Maximum theoretical range (in nm) = 1.23 x √H1 + 1.23 x √H2 The power of both the airborne and ground based transmitters will affect the range of the VDF. The bigger the power, the bigger the range. Intervening high ground will limit range, especially for low flying aircraft.

content.question: When do you have to select or not to select the BFO?

options.A: When receiving a N0N A1A, BFO must be selected OFF.
options.B: BFO is never required to be selected, it is only used for maintenance purposes.
options.C: When receiving a N0N A2A, BFO must be selected ON.
options.D: On most modern aircraft BFO is activated automatically.

key_points: LOs reference 062
learning.explanation: LOs reference 062.02.02.01.16: State that on modern aircraft, the BFO is activated automatically. Beat Frequency Oscillator (BFO) The purpose of a BFO is to allow an unmodulated transmission such as N0N/A1A to be heard. It works by adding a beat frequency to the frequency received from the NDB. These two frequencies are inputs to a heterodyne (frquency mixing unit). The mixing of the two frequencies produces an audible beat frequency, which is the difference of the two. On older equipement, there is a separate BFO button that can be pressed in order to identify unmodulated NDB signals. In modern aircraft, the BFO circuit has no push button, as the BFO is activated automatically when required.

content.question: You are making an approach to runway 25 at Daytona Beach which has a published ILS back-course approach. Which of the following statements is correct with respect to localiser indications on an omni-bearing indicator (OBI) and a horizontal situation indicator (HSI)?

options.A: The OBI will sense correctly with the front-course set. The HSI will sense correctly with the front-course set.
options.B: The OBI will sense correctly with the front-course set. The HSI will sense correctly with the back-course set.
options.C: Reverse sensing will always occur on the OBI regardless of the course set; the HSI will sense correctly with the back-course set.
options.D: Reverse sensing will always occur on the OBI regardless of the course set; the HSI will sense correctly with the front-course set.

key_points: An ILS localiser uses two lobes of differently modulated signals, one is modulated at 150 Hz and the other at 90 Hz, the ILS receiver on an aircraft interprets the amount of each signal as an indication of how far the aircraft is from the centre of the localiser, and on which side
This indication is shown directly on the display
The OBS (Omni Bearing Selector) which is used for VOR radial tracking does not have an impact on the displayed ILS readings
learning.explanation: An ILS localiser uses two lobes of differently modulated signals, one is modulated at 150 Hz and the other at 90 Hz, the ILS receiver on an aircraft interprets the amount of each signal as an indication of how far the aircraft is from the centre of the localiser, and on which side. This indication is shown directly on the display. The OBS (Omni Bearing Selector) which is used for VOR radial tracking does not have an impact on the displayed ILS readings. Using an omni-bearing indicator (OBI) display will always give a simple, fly left or fly right, localiser display no matter the chosen OBS course. A Horizontal Situation Indicator (HSI) has a simple Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) in the middle of the slaved gyro compass, which can be turned to face any direction, on the gyro compass, but when receiving ILS signals will only produce exactly the same display as the standard OBI, fly left or fly right. The direction of the CDI does not affect the CDI indications, just how we view them. When using a ILS back-course, the usual signal lobes are reversed, so an OBI display will be absolutely reverse sensing. This is the same for the CDI in the centre of the HSI, reverse sensing indications. However, the CDI in the middle of the HSI can be turned to face the front course of the standard ILS (needle pointing downwards when flying the back-course) which reverses our view of the indications again. This gives correctly sensing localiser indications for the HSI during a back-course approach, only if the CDI is set to the course of the standard inbound ILS.

content.question: In order to plot a bearing from a VOR station, a pilot needs to know the magnetic variation:

options.A: at the VOR
options.B: at the half-way point between the aircraft and the station
options.C: at both the VOR and aircraft

key_points: When plotting tracks and bearings on charts, they must be in "true" as opposed to magnetic
This is because all normal charts are referenced to true meridians
VORs, however, transmit their radials in terms of magnetic bearings
learning.explanation: When plotting tracks and bearings on charts, they must be in "true" as opposed to magnetic. This is because all normal charts are referenced to true meridians. VORs, however, transmit their radials in terms of magnetic bearings. This means that a variation must be applied from a VOR radial to get the true bearing we should plot on a chart. The variation to be used must be the variation at the VOR, as that is where the radials are emitted from, and thus is the position where the radial's direction was initially decided. An easy way to remember this is that V is for Variation and V is for VOR. If using NDB/ADF directions, then the direction of the incoming radio wave is decided at the aircraft, so the variation at the aircraft would be used.

content.question: At night, the Commander notices some erratic movement of the ADF needle. Although a specific NDB has been selected, the commander can also hear a second NDB identification code. What could be the reason?

options.A: The sky waves are eliminated at night making more power available to the ground waves, thus increasing the range and causing interference with distant stations.
options.B: The ionospheric reflections of the NDB Transmissions amplify the ground wave, increasing the range and causing interference with distant stations.
options.C: The ground wave component of an NDB extends to a far greater distance than the sky wave component, causing interference.
options.D: The sky wave component of an NDB extends to a far greater distance than the ground wave component, causing interference.

key_points: NIGHT EFFECT Night effect is due to the interference between ground waves and sky waves emitted by the same NDB station
The principal propagation method of NDBs is the ground wave
However, it is possible for weak sky waves to be returned at night when the ionosphere is less dense and attenuation is least
learning.explanation: NIGHT EFFECT Night effect is due to the interference between ground waves and sky waves emitted by the same NDB station. The principal propagation method of NDBs is the ground wave. However, it is possible for weak sky waves to be returned at night when the ionosphere is less dense and attenuation is least. Returning sky waves take a longer propagation path than ground waves so they are often out of phase. Night effect can be detected by listening for Fading on the carrier wave (BFO on) and by the instrument hunting. It is most likely at dawn or dusk.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
An aircraft is flying on a MH of 010°. The magnetic variation at the VOR is 10°W and at the aircraft 12°W. Which VOR-RMI corresponds to the indications on the HSI shown on the Annex?

options.A: Figure A
options.B: Figure D
options.C: Figure C

key_points: This type of question is best to draw out
To start with, draw the VOR (Magnetic North up) and lines coming out of it representing the course selected on the HSI (in this case radials 060º and 240º for the "TO" course - label them)

Now we can interpret the HSI as saying that the selected course is 060º TO the VOR (as the "TO" indication is filled in), so therefore we are near the "060º TO" line (the 240º radial we drew earlier), and are pointing towards the VOR (forget the actual heading for now) As we have full scale "fly right" indication, which means at least 10º fly right to get onto the course, we can draw our aircraft as being 10º (or more) left of the selected inbound course, meaning that we are between radial 250 and 330 (which is the 90º point from the course)
learning.explanation: This type of question is best to draw out. To start with, draw the VOR (Magnetic North up) and lines coming out of it representing the course selected on the HSI (in this case radials 060º and 240º for the "TO" course - label them). Now we can interpret the HSI as saying that the selected course is 060º TO the VOR (as the "TO" indication is filled in), so therefore we are near the "060º TO" line (the 240º radial we drew earlier), and are pointing towards the VOR (forget the actual heading for now) As we have full scale "fly right" indication, which means at least 10º fly right to get onto the course, we can draw our aircraft as being 10º (or more) left of the selected inbound course, meaning that we are between radial 250 and 330 (which is the 90º point from the course). At this point, it is important to remember that the RMIs simply point their needle at the beacon, so the tail of the RMI needle is the radial we are on (the head of the needle is the QDM - the opposite direction to the radial). Therefore, we just need to pick the RMI with a heading of 010º (which they all have) and the tail of the needle between 250º and 330º, which is Figure B. Variation is not a factor as the HSI, RMI and VOR radials are all in magnetic. ALTERNATIVE METHOD When you're more comfortable with the differences between CDIs, RMIs and HSIs, you can begin to take shortcuts, which are very useful when flying using these instruments. The alternative method (for use on HSIs only), is that the deviation indication + the arrow always point towards the VOR. We can then work out which quadrant the VOR is in. For instance, in this example, the VOR must be somewhere between 060º (the "TO" arrow) and 150º (the direction of the deviation bar). The head of the needle (on the RMIs) points directly at the VOR, so we just need to choose the RMI whose needle points between 060º and 150º, which is figure B.

content.question: An aircraft is being radar vectored for an ILS approach and is receiving the ILS ident correctly. When on the downwind leg, the pilots observe the ILS indications changing randomly and both the localiser and glide path showing warning flags intermittently. What is the most likely reason for this?

options.A: The aircraft is heading in the opposite direction to the localiser thus the indications are reversed and change frequently.
options.B: Lack of reception of the modulation signals due to a failure of the ground transmitters, so the aircraft receiver fails to lock onto the incoming signals.
options.C: Reflections from objects within the ILS coverage area leading to multipath signals outside the coverage area.
options.D: The ILS shows incorrect indications unless the aircraft is established on inbound course and on the glideslope, so such indications are normal during radar vectoring.

key_points: Learning Objective 062
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 062.02.05.04.08: Explain that multipath interference is caused by reflections from objects within the ILS coverage area. This question is not completely answerable from the question text alone, and the possible answers have to be considered to work out which one is correct. Therefore it is better to go through each and explain why it is correct/incorrect. A) "The aircraft is heading in the opposite direction to the localiser thus the indications are reversed and change frequently." The fact that the aircraft is probably heading around the opposite direction to the localiser on downwind does not mean that it would show erratic readings and intermittent flags. If flying outbound along the localiser track, it would reverse sense, but this is the only truth to this statement. B) "Lack of reception of the modulation signals due to a failure of the ground transmitters, so the aircraft receiver fails to lock onto the incoming signals." There is no known failure in the question, and this would remove the stable ident that is heard in the cockpit. C) "Reflections from objects within the ILS coverage area leading to multipath signals outside the coverage area." Now this one is possible. The signals that are being transmitted by the ILS localiser and glide path are just radio waves like any other, therefore they bounce off obstacles and can cause rather wild, erratic readings outside the coverage area. They can even cause wobbly readings within the coverage area. Therefore, this answer is correct. D) "The ILS shows incorrect indications unless the aircraft is established on inbound course and on the glideslope, so such indications are normal during radar vectoring." This option is far too specific. An ILS is still useful when more than half scale deflection left or right of the localiser, and when slightly above or below the glideslope, not only when fully established. In fact, there is a large and well published coverage area for LOC signals and for GP signals. It is correct that erratic indications are normal during radar vectoring, but not for this reason. Another potential cause that comes to mind is that the aircraft is flying through "fake localiser" side lobes, which are reverse sensing beams just outside of the coverage area, but these are usually a little more smooth than what is being asked in the question, and it is not one of the options in this question.

content.question: What is the usual indication when capturing a false ILS (Instrument Landing System) glide path signal?

options.A: Flag warning.
options.B: Red light on the Primary Flight Display (PFD).
options.C: No indication.

key_points: FALSE ILS GLIDE SLOPES False Glide Slopes refer to specific vertical paths in the vicinity of the runway's centerline, other than the established ILS glide path, where DDM is zero
These false glide slopes are actually side lobes

The presence of false glide slopes is attributed to various factors, including the presence of metallic structures near the transmitter and ground reflections, as well as the characteristics of the transmitting antenna
learning.explanation: FALSE ILS GLIDE SLOPES False Glide Slopes refer to specific vertical paths in the vicinity of the runway's centerline, other than the established ILS glide path, where DDM is zero. These false glide slopes are actually side lobes. The presence of false glide slopes is attributed to various factors, including the presence of metallic structures near the transmitter and ground reflections, as well as the characteristics of the transmitting antenna. Pilots should remain mindful of their existence. The first false glide slope typically occurs at an altitude approximately double the glide path angle, which is around 6 degrees for a standard 3-degree glide path. In regular flight procedures, pilots typically align with the localizer and intercept the glide slope from below. This ensures avoidance of intercepting false glide slopes. An indication of a false glidepath could be seen in the rate of descent or when cross-checking the altitude. If the rate of descent required is higher than stated in the charts, for example 1500 fpm instead of 500 fpm, the aircraft will be on a false glidepath. If the altitude passing at the specific DME distance is not the altitude described in the charts, for example 3 000 ft at 4.5 DME instead of 1 500 ft, the aircraft will be on a false glidepath. There is no warning flag appearing on the CDI, and that is the reason why many incidents have happened when aircraft intercepted false glide paths and pilots did not realize. CDI WARNING FLAG Regarding the Warning Flag, it appears under the following circumstances: Equipment failure on the aircraft's receiver. Ground station failure. Indicator malfunction. Weak signals received or the aircraft is out of the beacon's range.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The cockpit of a small aircraft has been fully set up to fly the appropriate ILS, and it has been identified. The crew have been given the final intercept heading and have been cleared for the approach. As the aircraft gets close enough to the localiser for it to come alive, the above situation is shown on the CDI (Course Deviation Indicator), with the glideslope about to reach the centre indication.
Which of these statements is correct?

options.A: The aircraft can only follow the glideslope when the localiser has reached the centre indication.
options.B: The aircraft is currently within the protected area of the ILS and is clear to follow the indications.
options.C: Descent on the glideslope can commence if the aircraft is turned to a heading similar to the localiser direction.
options.D: Descent on the glideslope can only commence when the localiser indication reaches 2.5 dots deviation.

key_points: The ILS glideslope is coming in very fast in this instance, and the pilots may not have time to fully intercept the localiser before passing through the glideslope
This is a problem in the current situation, as there is currently a nearly 4 dot deflection on the localiser CDI, and the aircraft is therefore not established on the localiser
An aircraft only becomes "established" on a localiser track when within half-scale deflection of the localiser centre line
learning.explanation: The ILS glideslope is coming in very fast in this instance, and the pilots may not have time to fully intercept the localiser before passing through the glideslope. This is a problem in the current situation, as there is currently a nearly 4 dot deflection on the localiser CDI, and the aircraft is therefore not established on the localiser. An aircraft only becomes "established" on a localiser track when within half-scale deflection of the localiser centre line. This is 2.5 dots of deviation on this display (the ring in the centre is the first dot in each direction). When established (2.5 dots or less deviation), the aircraft is within the protected area of the ILS approach, so can descend with the glideslope.

content.question: A Course Deviation Indicator (CDI) shows full deflection to the left when within range of a serviceable VOR. What angular deviation are you from the selected radial?

options.A: 10° or more.
options.B: 2.5° or more.
options.C: Less than 10°.

key_points: The deflection of the needle is proportional to the course deviation, but sensitivity and deflection vary depending on the system being used: When used with a VOR or VORTAC, the instrument can be referred to as an "omni bearing indicator" ("OBI")
The courseline is selected by turning an "omni bearing selector" or "OBS" knob usually located in the lower left of the indicator
It then shows the number of degrees deviation between the aircraft's current position and the "radial" line emanating from the signal source at the given bearing
learning.explanation: The deflection of the needle is proportional to the course deviation, but sensitivity and deflection vary depending on the system being used: When used with a VOR or VORTAC, the instrument can be referred to as an "omni bearing indicator" ("OBI"). The courseline is selected by turning an "omni bearing selector" or "OBS" knob usually located in the lower left of the indicator. It then shows the number of degrees deviation between the aircraft's current position and the "radial" line emanating from the signal source at the given bearing. This can be used to find and follow the desired radial. Deflection is 10° deviation at full scale (each side), with each dot on the CDI representing 2°. When used with a GPS, or other RNAV equipment, it shows actual distance left or right of the programmed courseline. Sensitivity is usually programmable or automatically switched, but 5 nautical miles (9.3 km) deviation at full scale is typical for en route operations. Approach and terminal operations have a higher sensitivity up to frequently 0.3 nautical miles (0.56 km) at full scale. In this mode, the OBS knob may or may not have an effect, depending on configuration. When used for instrument approaches using a LDA or ILS the OBS knob has no function because the courseline is usually the runway heading, and is determined by the ground transmitter. A CDI might incorporate a horizontal needle to provide vertical guidance when used with a precision ILS approach where the glideslope is broadcast by another transmitter located on the ground. Summary: when CDI is use with: VOR 2° per dot. Full scale deflection 10° ILS localiser 0.5° per dot. Full scale deflection 2.5° ILS glidepath 0.14° per dot. Full scale deflection 0.7°

content.question: What can be obtained on the NAV receiver by selecting one VHF frequency, in the range of 108 to 112 MHz?

options.A: Rho-theta information from an en-route VOR/DME station can be obtained.
options.B: Rho-theta information from a terminal VOR/DME can be obtained.
options.C: Theta-theta information from en-route VORs can be obtained.
options.D: Rho-rho information from an ILS/DME can be obtained.

key_points: The band 108 – 112 MHz is used by ILS Localizer and VOR, on different channels, while the band 112 – 118 MHz is used only by VOR
Within the band 108 – 112 MHz, all channels on even multiples of 100 kHz (108
learning.explanation: The band 108 – 112 MHz is used by ILS Localizer and VOR, on different channels, while the band 112 – 118 MHz is used only by VOR. Within the band 108 – 112 MHz, all channels on even multiples of 100 kHz (108.20, 108.40, etc) are used for VOR. Normally channels spaced 100 kHz are used, however, in congested areas also the intermediate channels (50 kHz) may be used. The VOR channels in this sub-band are usually used for terminal VOR, with short range. Within the 112 – 118 MHz portion of the band all channels (100 and 50 kHz) are available for VOR services. With regards to this question, it is important to establish the meaning of Rho and Theta. Rho represents Range (distance) and Theta represents Track (bearing). Rho-Rho could be DME/DME. Theta-Theta could represent VOR/NDB. Rho-Theta means VOR/DME or ILS/DME.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
An aircraft is flying an ILS approach and is descending with only a few seconds to go before reaching minimums. The indications on which of the above PFDs would require an immediate go-around?

options.A: Figure A
options.B: Figure B
options.C: Figure C

key_points: When on an ILS approach, an aircraft is only "protected" by a certain amount of guaranteed obstacle clearance when within the protected area
This protected area is half scale deflection on either side of the localiser (horizontal)

The aircraft cannot also deviate more than half scale deflection above or below the glideslope (vertical), meaning that the aircraft must go-around when outside of half scale deflection in any direction on either the glide slope or the localiser
learning.explanation: When on an ILS approach, an aircraft is only "protected" by a certain amount of guaranteed obstacle clearance when within the protected area. This protected area is half scale deflection on either side of the localiser (horizontal). The aircraft cannot also deviate more than half scale deflection above or below the glideslope (vertical), meaning that the aircraft must go-around when outside of half scale deflection in any direction on either the glide slope or the localiser. On these PFDs (Primary Flight Displays), half scale deflection is 1 dot. Figures B and D both have indications that are up to 1 dot deflection, but these are just within what is acceptable. Figure C has more than 1 dot "fly right" indication on the localiser, so must make an immediate go-around.

content.question: In accordance with ICAO Doc 8168, a pilot flying an NDB approach must achieve a tracking accuracy of within .... of the published approach track.

key_points: ICAO Doc 8168, Part I, Section 4 (Approach Procedures) 3

4 - Descent - The aircraft shall cross the fix or facility and fly outbound on the specified track, descending as necessary to the procedure altitude/height but no lower than the minimum crossing altitude/height associated with that segment
learning.explanation: ICAO Doc 8168, Part I, Section 4 (Approach Procedures) 3.3.4 - Descent - The aircraft shall cross the fix or facility and fly outbound on the specified track, descending as necessary to the procedure altitude/height but no lower than the minimum crossing altitude/height associated with that segment. If a further descent is specified after the inbound turn, this descent shall not be started until the aircraft is established on the inbound track. An aircraft is considered established when it is: a) within half full scale deflection for the ILS and VOR; or b) within ±5° of the required bearing for the NDB.

content.question: An ILS glide path provides azimuth coverage ...(i) each side of the localiser centreline to a distance of ...(ii) NM from the threshold.

key_points: Localiser Coverage From the center of the localiser aerial to 25 NM within ±10° of the approach bearing
From the center of the localiser aerial out to a distance of 17 NM within ±35° of the approach bearing
In some regions, where a steep angle glidepath is authorised, coverage is provided from the center of the localiser aerial to 18 NM ±10°, and 10 NM ±35°
learning.explanation: Localiser Coverage From the center of the localiser aerial to 25 NM within ±10° of the approach bearing. From the center of the localiser aerial out to a distance of 17 NM within ±35° of the approach bearing. In some regions, where a steep angle glidepath is authorised, coverage is provided from the center of the localiser aerial to 18 NM ±10°, and 10 NM ±35°. Upper limit of the localizer signal vertical coverage is a minimum of 7° above the localizer horizontal plane. The protection range and height of ILS is 25 NM / 6 250 ft. Note 1: Any attempt to use the localiser outside the areas listed above may lead to false/reverse sense indications. Use outside designated coverage areas is therefore not permitted. Glidepath Coverage Vertical coverage from 0.45 θ to 1.75 θ above the horizontal through the ILS threshold (θ = glide path angle). This equates to 1.35° to 5.25° above the threshold horizontal for a nominal 3° glide path. Horizontal coverage extending in azimuth 8° either side of the extended centerline out to a range of 10 NM. The protection range and height of ILS is 25 NM / 6 250 ft. Note 2: Example of the glideslope vertical coverage calculation. For a glideslope of 3.3° the vertical coverage is as follows: 0.45 × 3.3° = approx. 1.49° (lower edge) 1.75 × 3.3° = approx. 5.77° (upper edge)

content.question: The captain of an aircraft flying at FL100 wishes to obtain weather information at the destination airfield (0 ft MSL) from the airfields VOR. Assuming ISA conditions, what is the approximate maximum theoretical range at which it can be expected to obtain this information?

options.A: 125 NM
options.B: 125 km

key_points: VORs transmit their signals via VHF (Very High Frequency) radio transmissions
These travel in straight lines, and will not go through solid objects such as buildings, mountains, the ocean, etc
This question mentions gaining the aerodrome weather from the VOR, which is possible as many airfield VORs have the ATIS readout on the VOR audio frequency
learning.explanation: VORs transmit their signals via VHF (Very High Frequency) radio transmissions. These travel in straight lines, and will not go through solid objects such as buildings, mountains, the ocean, etc. This question mentions gaining the aerodrome weather from the VOR, which is possible as many airfield VORs have the ATIS readout on the VOR audio frequency. We call these signals "line-of-sight", as, if the antennas can "see" each other, they can transmit between each other. Of course, that depends on the power of the transmission, as higher power transmitters allow for a greater range. With the Earth being curved, this does pose a problem for long range transmissions between aircraft and ground stations, as the aircraft may not be within line of sight of the ground station. The ways to fix this are to get closer or go higher. The higher the aircraft gets, the further it can "see", so that means it can communicate with radio stations further away. The formula for the expected range of a transmission (Earth curvature limited) is: Distance (nm) = 1.23 x sqrt( height of transmitter (ft) ) + 1.23 x sqrt( height of receiver (ft) ) If either the transmitter or receiver is at sea level (0 ft), then you can cut out one term from the equation, making it: Distance (nm) = 1.23 x sqrt( height (ft) ) In this case, we are at FL 100 (10 000 ft), so our maximum range is; 1.23 x sqrt(10 000) = 1.23 x 100 = 123 nm (closest answer 125 nm)

content.question: The pilot is performing an ILS CAT II approach when a car crosses the sensitive area without clearance. The pilot executes a missed approach. Explain why the pilot performed the missed approach.

options.A: The ILS signal most likely suffered from unacceptable interference, resulting in fluctuations of the cockpit display indicators.
options.B: The car has caused an ILS signal interference, such interference most likely resulted in autopilot disengagement.
options.C: The magnetic variation changed due to the car crossing the sensitive area.
options.D: A change of polarization was observed as a consequence of the vehicle trespassing the sensitive area.

key_points: The ILS sensitive area is an area extending beyond the critical area where the parking and/or movement of vehicles, including aircraft, is controlled to prevent the possibility of unacceptable interference to the ILS signal during ILS operations
Effects of infringements of critical and sensitive areas It has been shown that critical and sensitive area violations have an effect on the aircraft systems
The magnitude and impact of these effects is dependent upon many factors including aircraft type, position, speed, geometry, equipment, size and speed of the violating object
learning.explanation: The ILS sensitive area is an area extending beyond the critical area where the parking and/or movement of vehicles, including aircraft, is controlled to prevent the possibility of unacceptable interference to the ILS signal during ILS operations. Effects of infringements of critical and sensitive areas It has been shown that critical and sensitive area violations have an effect on the aircraft systems. The magnitude and impact of these effects is dependent upon many factors including aircraft type, position, speed, geometry, equipment, size and speed of the violating object. Aircraft systems may absorb short time ILS signal fluctuations through the effects of filtering by on-board equipment and the dynamics of the airframe. Slow or bias type errors that are not detected by the anomaly detection algorithms result in indications to the pilot either through flags, aircraft control actions (from autopilot) or fluctuations of the cockpit display indicators. The length and magnitude of fluctuations are linked to the speed and time of the critical and / or sensitive area violation. FAA warns pilots of reports that ILS signal integrity is affected by equipment operating within the ILS critical area. " In several cases, the aircraft autopilot followed ILS fluctuations causing the aircraft to pitch and roll excessively" (FAA). Note: this question has been created based on incomplete feedback. We would kindly ask that you report it back to us if you come across it in your official exam.

content.question: How can a DME interrogator distinguish between its own reply pulse pairs and the reply pulse pairs of other aircraft in the area, using the same DME station?

options.A: The DME transponder uses a slightly different, randomly varying, delay for each interrogating aircraft.
options.B: The Pulse Repetition Frequency of the pulse pairs transmitted by the interrogator varies, for each interrogator, in a unique rhythm.
options.C: The time interval between both pulses of consecutive pulse pairs transmitted by the interrogator varies, for each interrogator, in a unique pattern.
options.D: On the Y-channel the time interval between the pulses of an interrogator pulse pair is 36 msec and of a transponder pulse pair 30 m/sec.

key_points: DME uses the UHF frequency band, between 962 - 1213 MHz

The aircraft DME equipment radiated coded pulse pairs which is then received at the ground station, triggering the transponder to send a suitably-formatted reply adjusted by +/- 63 MHz, after a delay of 50 microseconds
For each of the interrogation channels, two reply frequencies are allocated, one is 63 MHz higher than the transmission and the other 63 MHz lower
learning.explanation: DME uses the UHF frequency band, between 962 - 1213 MHz. The aircraft DME equipment radiated coded pulse pairs which is then received at the ground station, triggering the transponder to send a suitably-formatted reply adjusted by +/- 63 MHz, after a delay of 50 microseconds. For each of the interrogation channels, two reply frequencies are allocated, one is 63 MHz higher than the transmission and the other 63 MHz lower. The reason for using pulse pairs is to ensure the receivers do no accept random single pulses or other transmissions that are not addressed for this type of communication. Each pulse pair is spaced at 12 microseconds (X channels) or 36 microseconds (Y channels), and the space of each pair of Pulse Pairs is different between each group and is randomly unique to each transmission.

Radio Magnetic Indicator - RMI: The QDM can be read anytime at the needle’s pointer, the QDR at the needle’s end

Radio Magnetic Indicator - RMI: The QDM can be read anytime at the needle’s pointer, the QDR at the needle’s end.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
On the EHSI the ADF was tuned to the KUS NDB. What is the QDR for the KUS NDB?

key_points: For ADF their needle will always point towards the NDB
The head of the needle indicates the QDM, and the tail indicates QDR for the tuned NDB on a compass card/rose fed with magnetic heading
The nail shaped symbol on the compass rose represents the head or tail of the needle
learning.explanation: For ADF their needle will always point towards the NDB. The head of the needle indicates the QDM, and the tail indicates QDR for the tuned NDB on a compass card/rose fed with magnetic heading. The nail shaped symbol on the compass rose represents the head or tail of the needle. We can see the blue nail between 230 and 235 degrees on the compass rose, with the sharp end pointing downward – which means it is the tail of the needle. The reading will be 232.5 degrees. (Midpoint between 230 and 235). Now if we look at the bottom left corner it was written “ADF 1 KUS” in blue, and that means the blue nail is associated with that NDB (1 means radio aid number 1). Combining all the information above we can deduce that the QDR for KUS NDB is 232.5 degrees. The nearest choice will be 232 degrees. Notes for further learning: The green nail at 170 degrees represent the second radio aid tuned for display. It has the sharp end pointing upward which means it is the head of the needle. Normally we should see some words on the bottom right corner like “ADF 2 NH” for example (in green colour). Somehow it was not shown in this annex. The aircraft is now tracking TO a VOR, as indicated by the solid white triangle (TO symbol pointing upward) ahead of the hollow white triangle (the symbol representing the aircraft). The identification of the VOR we are tracking to usually appears on the top right corner, but not in this case somehow. “NAV” on the top right corner most probably means we are in navigation mode, tracking on course 197 degrees (solid magenta line), on 017 radial of the VOR while almost centred and at 8.3NM from it. White solid line at 194 degrees is our current track with range markers on it.

content.question: A tuned ILS can be identified through a Morse code which is:

options.A: Decoded in text, showing the frequency and runway number.
options.B: Made visible through the three flashing marker lights.
options.C: Made audible via the audio control panel in NAV.
options.D: Shown on the related ILS localiser display.

key_points: The audible identifier of an ILS is normally a 3-letter Morse Code that represents the 3-letter identifier of the ILS
It may also be plain text
The Morse Code identifier is transmitted every 10 seconds on the audible channel of the ILS by modulating the localiser frequency
learning.explanation: The audible identifier of an ILS is normally a 3-letter Morse Code that represents the 3-letter identifier of the ILS. It may also be plain text. The Morse Code identifier is transmitted every 10 seconds on the audible channel of the ILS by modulating the localiser frequency. This does not affect the display of the ILS information in the aircraft. The Morse Code may be made audible via the audio control panel in NAV. For instance, on the boeing 737-800 Audio Control Panel, there is no separate “ILS” selector. NAV 1 or 2 will work for both VOR or ILS, whatever is tuned on VHF NAV 1 or 2.

content.question: Which of the following is an advantage of Ground/DF (VDF) let-down?

options.C: It is pilot interpreted and does not require the assistance of ATC
options.D: It does not require any special equipment, apart from a VHF radio, to be installed in the aircraft or on the ground

key_points: VDF stands for VHF Direction Finding
This is an aid for the pilot to determine his position and heading more accurately
Some modern aerodromes have newer radio aerials that can sense the direction of VHF-COM signals directly from an airplane
learning.explanation: VDF stands for VHF Direction Finding. This is an aid for the pilot to determine his position and heading more accurately. Some modern aerodromes have newer radio aerials that can sense the direction of VHF-COM signals directly from an airplane. An advantage of VDF is that there is only one specific airborne equipment required which is a VHF-radio. The ability of VDF depends on the ground station, not on the aircraft equipment.

content.question:
Consider the following situations. An aircraft is flying:
1. directly towards a DME
2. directly away from a DME
3. a DME ARC
4. passing abeam a DME station.
In which of the above given situations should the DME give an accurate groundspeed reading?

options.A: 1 and 2
options.C: 1, 2 and 3

key_points: The DME may have a function to display the Ground Speed (GS) read-out
However, this actually presents the rate of change of the distance relative to the DME which does not necessarily approximate the actual GS of the aircraft

For the GS read-out to be correct, there are some conditions which need to be fullfiled: The direction relative to the DME should be such that the aircraft tracks exactly towards or away from the DME due to the relative motion measurement from the station
learning.explanation: The DME may have a function to display the Ground Speed (GS) read-out. However, this actually presents the rate of change of the distance relative to the DME which does not necessarily approximate the actual GS of the aircraft. For the GS read-out to be correct, there are some conditions which need to be fullfiled: The direction relative to the DME should be such that the aircraft tracks exactly towards or away from the DME due to the relative motion measurement from the station. On the other hand, for instance, when flying on a DME arc where distance is kept constant, the GS read out equals zero. The distance from the DME should be high because the speed estimate is a rate of change in the slant range and not the ground range. Consequently, when the aircraft flies close to or above the DME, the GS read-out is lower than the actual GS.

content.question: MLS can overcome ILS siting problems, since MLS signals...

options.A: can be interrupted to prevent unwanted reflections.
options.B: can penetrate through buildings to allow even transmission.
options.C: are transmitted from one antenna.
options.D: follow the curvature of the terrain.

key_points: The Microwave Landing System (MLS) was developed as an advanced precision approach system to replace the Instrument Landing System (ILS)
It aimed to address the limitations of ILS and offer enhanced flexibility to its users
Microwave Landing System (MLS) features: Worldwide availability with 200 channels
learning.explanation: The Microwave Landing System (MLS) was developed as an advanced precision approach system to replace the Instrument Landing System (ILS). It aimed to address the limitations of ILS and offer enhanced flexibility to its users. Microwave Landing System (MLS) features: Worldwide availability with 200 channels. Azimuth coverage of at least ±40° of the runway's on-course line (QDM) and allows selection of glide slopes ranging from 0.9° to 20°. Usable range extends up to 20-30 NM from the MLS site. The MLS incorporates a built-in Distance Measuring Equipment (DME). Includes a secondary system for back course transmissions, offering guidance within ±20° of the runway direction up to 15° in elevation, within a range of 10 NM and up to a height of 10,000 ft. Operates in the SHF band (5031 - 5090.7 MHz), allowing installation in hilly areas without the need for site leveling. The MLS scanning beam can be interrupted to avoid reflections, eliminating course deviation errors caused by aircraft, vehicles, and buildings. Increased azimuth and elevation coverage enables aircraft to choose their own approaches, improving runway utilization and benefiting helicopters and STOL aircraft. MLS is designed to be compatible with various navigation instruments and systems, including conventional localizer and glide path instruments, EFIS (Electronic Flight Instrument System), auto-pilot systems, and area navigation equipment. MLS provides positive automatic landing indications and clear on/off flag indications for the localizer and glide slope needles. The identification prefix for MLS consists of an 'M' followed by two letters. The goal is for all aircraft equipped with MLS to operate according to CAT III criteria.

content.question: An aircraft is on radial 055 from a nearby VOR, with a course of 060 set on the HSI. What will the HSI indicate?

options.A: TO with a fly-left indication.
options.B: FROM with a fly-left indication.
options.C: TO with a fly-right indication.

key_points: This type of question is best to draw out

To start with, draw the VOR (Magnetic North up) and lines coming out of it representing the course selected on the HSI (in this case radials 060° and the reciprocal 240° - you could also label them 060 FROM and 060 TO respectively)
Then draw the aircraft on radial 055°, probably it is easiest to draw it pointing in a similar direction of the HSI course as the heading is not given, as this is the most easily understood scenario
learning.explanation: This type of question is best to draw out. To start with, draw the VOR (Magnetic North up) and lines coming out of it representing the course selected on the HSI (in this case radials 060° and the reciprocal 240° - you could also label them 060 FROM and 060 TO respectively). Then draw the aircraft on radial 055°, probably it is easiest to draw it pointing in a similar direction of the HSI course as the heading is not given, as this is the most easily understood scenario. Now we can see that the aircraft is very close to the 060 radial, which we called the "060° FROM" course, and this is what our HSI will guide us to follow. As you can see in the annex above, or in your drawing, to follow the 060° course outbound from the VOR (the 060 radial), the aircraft is left of the course (as long as it is pointing in the correct direction). This will therefore provide a FROM arrow and a fly-right indication. We have set the heading as 020° in our depiction, but this makes no difference to the indication shown on the CDI in the middle of the HSI, which is what we must assume the examiner is asking about, it just makes things less cluttered. This particular depiction could perhaps occur if you were trying to intercept the 060 radial outbound (from original heading 020°) but overshot it.

content.question: MLS is primarily being installed at airports where

options.A: meteorological conditions are likely to cause ILS ducting by super refraction.
options.B: the main approach paths lead over water.
options.C: ILS encounters difficulties because of surrounding buildings and/or the terrain or interference from local music stations.
options.D: topographical conditions preclude the installation of ILS marker beacons.

key_points: The Microwave Landing System (MLS) was designed to replace ILS with an advanced precision approach system that would overcome the disadvantages of ILS and also provide greater flexibility to its users
However, there are few MLS installations in use at present and they are likely to co-exist with ILS for a long time
MLS is a precision approach and landing system that provides position information and various ground to air data
learning.explanation: The Microwave Landing System (MLS) was designed to replace ILS with an advanced precision approach system that would overcome the disadvantages of ILS and also provide greater flexibility to its users. However, there are few MLS installations in use at present and they are likely to co-exist with ILS for a long time. MLS is a precision approach and landing system that provides position information and various ground to air data. The position information is provided in a wide coverage sector and is determined by an azimuth angle measurement, an elevation measurement and a range measurement. MLS has the ability to interrupt the transmitted signal to avoid reflection by stationary objects (such as obstructions in the appropach path) which makes the system less sensitive to geographic location and obstacles. This and the relatively low cost of the system are its main advantages. Subsidiary advantages are the ability of MLS equipped aircraft to fly approach paths other than straight in and the single frequency used avoiding the requirement for frequency pairing.

content.question: "The area where vehicles and aircraft are excluded" related to ILS operations is the definition of the...

options.A: ILS Critical Area.
options.B: ILS Sensitive Area.
options.C: ILS Coverage Area.

key_points: ICAO Annex 10 Volume I ATTACHMENT C 2
Material concerning ILS installations 2
learning.explanation: ICAO Annex 10 Volume I ATTACHMENT C 2. Material concerning ILS installations 2.1.9.2 ILS critical and sensitive areas. States differ in the way they choose to identify ILS protection areas. Practices also differ in how vehicle movement restrictions are managed. One method is to identify critical areas and sensitive areas as follows: a) the ILS critical area is an area of defined dimensions about the localizer and glide path antennas where vehicles, including aircraft, are excluded during all ILS operations. The critical area is protected because the presence of vehicles and/or aircraft inside its boundaries will cause unacceptable disturbance to the ILS signal-in-space; b) the ILS sensitive area is an area where the parking and/or movement of vehicles, including aircraft, is controlled to prevent the possibility of unacceptable interference to the ILS signal during ILS operations. The sensitive area is protected against interference caused by large moving objects outside the critical area but still normally within the airfield boundary.

content.question: The magnetic variation at the VOR station and at the aircraft is 8°E. An aircraft is on a bearing of 036°(T) from the VOR and its heading is 330°(T). What OBS setting would make the CDI needle centre with the "TO" indication showing?

key_points: As the aircraft is on a true bearing of 036° from the VOR (true radial), we can convert than very easily into a magnetic radial
Variation East, Magnetic Least
Variation West, Magnetic Best
learning.explanation: As the aircraft is on a true bearing of 036° from the VOR (true radial), we can convert than very easily into a magnetic radial. Variation East, Magnetic Least. Variation West, Magnetic Best. Variation is 8°E, so the magnetic radial is 36 - 8 = 028° To centre the CDI (course deviation indicator) indication, the OBS (omni bearing selector) needs to be selecting either the outbound course (radial) or the inbound course (QDM). In this case, we want the inbound course (QDM), as the question wants the "TO" indication showing. Therefore, we need the QDM, which is the opposite of the radial. QDM = 028° + 180° = 208° The heading does not make a difference, there is no heading input into the CDI.

content.question: Flying over Russia DME slant range reads 1.5 NM. The aircraft on the approach is flying 1000 m above the DME elevation. The distance from your ground position to the DME station is:

key_points: You can solve this exercise using Pythagoras’ theorem
First step: convert 1
5 NM into metres
learning.explanation: You can solve this exercise using Pythagoras’ theorem. First step: convert 1.5 NM into metres. 1.5 x 6080/3.28 = 2780.5 m Second step: Pythagoras theorem (2780.5)2 = (Ground distance)2 + 10002 (Ground distance)2 = (2780.5)2 - 10002 (Ground distance)2 = 6731180 Ground distance = sq root 6731180 Ground distance = 2594.5 m
